userreviews.userReview: I didn't find much useful or tempting in here, but then again I'm not a vegetarian.

What the hell is Polenta? Before this book I was afraid of Polenta. I never knew what to do with it. Now, just seeing some simple ideas had incorporated a whole new grain to my regime. I love the little paragraphs interspersed throughout the book like one entitled "Fear of Tofu!" I love the simplicity of this book. It is all in the title. Obviously you can add to the recipes to make them your own but they are perfect for a new vegetarian or anyone that wants to eat healthier.

I have tried a variety of the recipes in this book and find them easy to make and the ingredients are not hard to find either. Although I'm generally not a fan of cookbooks without pictures (I like to know what the final product was supposed to look like), the recipes in the 5-Ingredient cookbook were straightforward enough that I felt comfortable trying them without visual aid.

I started marking recipes that sounded good but then I had to stop because I was marking most of them. That's a sign of a good cookbook to me because I won't mark off the recipes I don't think I can do or would like. Now if I can only go through all of them to decide on which one to start with...
Excellent easy to understand instructions to make wonderful, tasty and easy vegetarian recipes.

Glad to learn the basics in the beginning such as how long you keep your grains which never paid close attention once I lived alone. I tend to let things mold or get old, or taste funny and wonder why like beans. I do check expiration dates if not frozen which can last longer up to 6 months to a year.There's some parts I skimmed through, didn't seem rather important to me like the shopping list with her husband, but could be a cutesy touch for those who have families or mate. Will review recipes to see if there's anything I can try or use. So far, the one that caught my eye is sweet potato soup. (Other recipes weren't appetizing to me then again not necessarily a vegetarian but like to eat vegetarian meals every now and then for cleansing, detoxing, or fasting). Not into cold soups either as some are suggested or offered in the book. Not big on microwaving foods, unless to heat up. I'll see which ones I can use, jot down, and tweak when I try it.Will have to retry soy cheeses but done the vegetarian and soy meat products. Not sure if scallions is a meat substitute but see this used quite frequently in a number of recipes. I viewed this as a meat, seafood, may have to verify since this is mentioned in vegetarian book. I do it with Chinese seafood platters, and pretty good.I saw a recipe to mix greens and black-eye peas together, I love both but prefer to eat them separate on the plate, not sure about making them together in a soup pot.Okay but only copied a few recipes out of the whole book. Leisure read, 2014.

This book is a little cheese-heavy for my taste, but with my new addiction to Daiya, I thought I'd give it a try.Baba Ghanoush: Mine came out a little lemony but the recipe was easy to follow. I like roasting the eggplants whole!Fruited Couscous: I can't believe I've been using the wrong proportion of liquid to couscous! (It should be 2:1, I was reminded by this recipe.) Anyway, this recipe really uses more than 5 ingredients, unless you buy a 4-oz. bag of "dried fruit bits" -- but it was great, nice and fluffy, and it paired well with the baba ghanoush and pita bread.Baked Barbecue Tofu and Peppers: Yum yum! Everyone loved this and it was easy. Onions and peppers pair nicely with BBQ tofu.Simple Potato Salad: Jeff loved this. I thought it was a little simple for my taste, but with the addition of some capers, I loved it.Black-Eyed Peas with Greens: I thought 2 tbsp of balsamic vinegar was a little much, but otherwise this basic saute was delish. I served it with roasted sweet potatoes.

This was one of my favorite cook books when I was just starting out cooking on my own. It was a great guide for a beginner because long lists of ingredients, even spices, scared me away from a potentially delicious dinner. I still use it often for quick week night meals. I like that many of her recipes don't include a milk product, and she pulls in ingredients from all around the world. She also doesn't include very many pre-processed ingredients, which is no small feat for a cook book centered on recipes with only 5 ingredients.

So far the several recipes I've tried from this have been extremely easy, and just different enough. We especially liked the curried lentils and spinach recipe. The recipes can be slightly bland, which in a way is nice because I can choose my own level of spiciness, etc. (and I am a total weenie about spiciness).P.S. I really liked the "Creamy" Mushroom Soup recipe. But don't cook it too long! The nice, creamy texture gets clumpy. :(

This is the best cookbook I have come across in a long time. Normally you have to choose what is most important to you - a vegetarian cookbook with fattening recipes, or a healthy vegetarian cookbook that requires 50,000 ingredients, or a simply healthy cookbook that is not vegetarian? I have FINALLY found one that encompasses all: Vegetarian, healthy, 5 ingredients per recipe. And the recipes are fantastic.

A simple, easy to use cookbook, packed with useful information and flexible recipes. It's great for vegetarians on tight budgets of both time and money. And while most of these dishes can use a little spicing up, adjustments and substitutions for personal tastes, the basic ingredients are the perfect starting place. One of the advantages of this book is that each recipe lists several side dishes that compliment it. This cookbook should be on every vegetarian's bookshelf!

I stumbled upon this cookbook when living in Tucson with a family of hippies who had a no-meat-in-the-house policy -- this saved me from night after endless night of lackluster quesadillas and peanut butter sandwiches. Every recipe does indeed boast no more than five ingredients, providing you with the backbone of several tasty dishes you can embellish with further garnishing or enjoy as is. Perfect for any frugal, time-strapped quasi-vegetarian.

I'm really excited about this cookbook -- my vegetarian friend Sara made a recipe from it, so simple and tasty. I flipped through it and felt it would be a worthy purchase, particularly for those nights I'm willing to stop at the grocery store before I go home, but I'm not in the mood to make a complicated meal. Perfect!

The best vegetarian cookbook I've ever bought! I love cooking, but recipes listing 10-15 ingredients overwhelm me and rarely get made. The simplicity of these recipes really helped me learn how to put together delicious vegetarian meals without spending inordinate amounts of time in the kitchen. Many of my favorite recipes have come out of this book.

No photos but recipes have a nice, easily-skimmed layout. The directions, however, are in a light-gray font that looks completely faded out in less-than-bright light. Eleven chapters with a nice section on menu planning. Overall, I like this book. It has simple, no-frills recipes with fairly standard pantry ingredients. A good choice for cooks who like to keep things simple.

The problem I have with vegetarian cookbooks is that I am extremely allergic to soy. I strike against this book was liberal use of soy products. I did find and even try enough recipes to like the books.

I'm not a vegetarian but want to cook healthier meals. I found several tasty recipes for Dax, who has a new found love for tofu. I like the fact the recipes have few ingredients. I borrowed this from the library, but marked so many recipes I'll probably buy it.

I liked the premise of only a few ingredients, but the author almost never stuck with that. Sure, there were not huge ingredient lists, but several items required more than 5 items. Good book, though, and I will use several recipes.

This is a good introductory vegetarian cookbook, as well as handy for cooks who want quick, simple meals. It's not my favorite by this author, simply because I'm not the type of cook who wants simple! Cooking is my joy and stress reliever, so I prefer lots of work!
it's good... ish... just somehow... yeah
Several good ideas, though not enough to appeal to our family
Eh….very simplistic. I would've appreciated this cookbook more in college when I knew zero about cooking and wanted simple things.
Does not include pictures (which I hate), but does have short ingredients lists (which I love.) Got a few good recipes, especially for cabbage.
I use this cookbook several times a week. It's full of delicious and easy to make recipies.
great, easy ideas for quick vegetarian meals, though sometimes limiting dishes to 5 ingredients sacrifices some flavor. Overall though a godsend for busy vegetarians like me!
Just got this book and have already used one recipe (it was good). Found lots of other recipes that I will be trying out in the next month.
The recipes in this book are simple and awesome! Good for everyday basic cooking.
Five ingredients is all i can afford anyway!
extremely simple recipes

description: "Nava Atlas has solutions for maintaining sophisticated flavors in the dishes she creates and still manages to keep the ingredients healthy." --Cooking Light Eating healthfully is a challenge for those with fast-paced lives. In The Vegetarian 5-Ingredient Gourmet,  Nava Atlas pares meal preparation down to the essentials, using just a few high-quality ingredients in each delicious dish. Focusing on whole foods and fresh produce (with a little help from convenient natural sauces and condiments) she serves up a varied range of choices for everyday fare.More than 250 recipes include soups, salads, and pastas; grain, bean, and soy entrees; wraps and sandwich fillings; simple side dishes; fruit-filled finales; and more. The full-flavored fare made from five ingredients or less includes Curried Red Lentil and Spinach Soup; Greek-Flavored Potato Salad; Black Bean Nachos Grandes; Baked Barbecue Tofu and Peppers; and Miniature Fresh Fruit Tarts. Filled with ingenious shortcuts and sprinkled with kitchen wisdom and tips throughout, The Vegetarian 5-Ingredient Gourmet also offers the reader dozens of menu suggestions to help make meal planning effortless.From sophisticated (Mixed Greens with Pears, Cranberries, and Goat Cheese) to kid-friendly (Peanut Butter Noodles), here are recipes to suit every taste. Nava Atlas makes it simple for busy families or active singles to eat the kind of high-nutrient foods everyone needs and to enjoy the robust flavors everyone craves.
title: The Vegetarian 5-Ingredient Gourmet
